linkTarget.anchoringText: The A4 reservoir is a shallow anticlinal structure that is bounded by two main faults. An internal fault divides the reservoir into two fault blocks: Main and West fault blocks. The two fault blocks share a common OOWC and are also connected in the down-dip oil leg. No OGOCs were logged by the wells that penetrated the reservoir rather Highest Known Oil (HKO) were encountered (see Figure 1)

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Structural Map of A4 Reservoir with Initial Fluid Distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural Map of A4 Reservoir with Initial Fluid Distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: The comprehensive simulation of A4 reservoir involved the use of a structured workflow for the simulation project (see Figure 2). First, the earth models with static uncertainties were created by the geologist. The earth models are reviewed by the engineer to ensure that the static data were consistent. Then, the engineer reviews the historical production/injection/pressure data and quality checks the data to identify any erroneous and inconsistent data. Thereafter, the engineer reviews the dynamic input data before carrying out deterministic history-match

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Comprehensive History Match Workflow for A4 reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comprehensive History Match Workflow for A4 reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Each of the above static properties has their low, mid and high realization values. Thus, there were 243 realizations of earth models. The dimension of the earth model is 64 × 102 × 41 (I × J × K); while the average dimension of each grid block is 45m × 45m × 1.5ft. The total number of active grid blocks in the base model is about 81,000 grid blocks. With this low number of active grid blocks and considering the fast run time for the model, there was no need to upscale the model. Thus, the model used in this work is the original fine grid from the geologist. Figure 3 shows fine grid of the base model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Fine grid Earth Model of A4 Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fine grid Earth Model of A4 Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition the test/allocated GOR are inconsistent with the FTHP except at early production time. Thus, it was decided that only the initial produced GOR for A4-1p will be considered for history match as far as GOR match is concerned. However, the allocated oil rate, shut-in bottom-hole pressure, FTHP and water cut for all the historical production period of A4-1p will be history matched (see Figure 4). The A4-2p well has good consistency between the well test oil rate and allocated oil rate. However, the allocated GOR is more consistent with the FTHP compared to the well test GOR. It was decided to consider all the allocated GOR history of A4-2p for history match. In addition, the allocated oil rate, FTHP and water cut for all the historical production period of A4-2p will be history matched (see Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Production/Pressure data quality check for well A4-1p

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production/Pressure data quality check for well A4-1p

linkTarget.anchoringText: In addition the test/allocated GOR are inconsistent with the FTHP except at early production time. Thus, it was decided that only the initial produced GOR for A4-1p will be considered for history match as far as GOR match is concerned. However, the allocated oil rate, shut-in bottom-hole pressure, FTHP and water cut for all the historical production period of A4-1p will be history matched (see Figure 4). The A4-2p well has good consistency between the well test oil rate and allocated oil rate. However, the allocated GOR is more consistent with the FTHP compared to the well test GOR. It was decided to consider all the allocated GOR history of A4-2p for history match. In addition, the allocated oil rate, FTHP and water cut for all the historical production period of A4-2p will be history matched (see Figure 5).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Production/Pressure data quality check for well A4-2p

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production/Pressure data quality check for well A4-2p

linkTarget.anchoringText: As there was no lab PVT data for A4 reservoir, the best black oil PVT correlation that matched the lab PVT data for an analog reservoir in the field was used in this work. Table 1 shows the lab PVT summary of an analog reservoir in the field. Using the basic oil properties of the A4 reservoir and applying the selected PVT correlation, the PVT data for A4 was generated for this work (see Figure 6). Based on SCAL data from reservoirs in the field, the mid relative permeability values are shown in Figure 7.

As there was no lab PVT data for A4 reservoir, the best black oil PVT correlation that matched the lab PVT data for an analog reservoir in the field was used in this work. Table 1 shows the lab PVT summary of an analog reservoir in the field. Using the basic oil properties of the A4 reservoir and applying the selected PVT correlation, the PVT data for A4 was generated for this work (see Figure 6). Based on SCAL data from reservoirs in the field, the mid relative permeability values are shown in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Relative Permeability Table for A4 Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative Permeability Table for A4 Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The input history-match parameters were tuned until an acceptable history-match was obtained with the base model. Table 2 shows the values of the input history-match parameters that gave acceptable history-match. Figures 8 and 9 show the history-match plots of GOR, Oil Rate, SBHP/FTHP and water cut for A4-1p and A4-2p, respectively. For A4-1p, good history-match was obtained for initial produced GOR, SBHP, FTHP and water cut. In the same vein, reasonable history-match was obtained for A4-2p with respect to the GOR, FTHP and water cut.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Deterministic History match plot of A4-1p for the Base Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Deterministic History match plot of A4-1p for the Base Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The input history-match parameters were tuned until an acceptable history-match was obtained with the base model. Table 2 shows the values of the input history-match parameters that gave acceptable history-match. Figures 8 and 9 show the history-match plots of GOR, Oil Rate, SBHP/FTHP and water cut for A4-1p and A4-2p, respectively. For A4-1p, good history-match was obtained for initial produced GOR, SBHP, FTHP and water cut. In the same vein, reasonable history-match was obtained for A4-2p with respect to the GOR, FTHP and water cut.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Deterministic History match plot of A4-2p for the Base Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Deterministic History match plot of A4-2p for the Base Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The history-match result for the OGOC sensitivity runs are shown only for A4-2p as its model produced GOR is more sensitive to assumed OGOC since it is completed higher in the reservoir than A4-1p. Figures 10 to Figure 12 show the effect of varying OGOC on the history-match quality for A4-2p. In Figures 10 to 12, the blue colored lines are the base case model, the red colored lines are the runs from sensitivity of the OGOC, while the green colored circles are the actual historical data. Figure 10 shows the comparison between the history-match quality for the base case (OGOC at 4350 ft-tvd) and OGOC at 4360 ft-tvd.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at 4360 ft-tvd

formatted-caption.caption-text: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at 4360 ft-tvd

linkTarget.anchoringText: The history-match result for the OGOC sensitivity runs are shown only for A4-2p as its model produced GOR is more sensitive to assumed OGOC since it is completed higher in the reservoir than A4-1p. Figures 10 to Figure 12 show the effect of varying OGOC on the history-match quality for A4-2p. In Figures 10 to 12, the blue colored lines are the base case model, the red colored lines are the runs from sensitivity of the OGOC, while the green colored circles are the actual historical data. Figure 10 shows the comparison between the history-match quality for the base case (OGOC at 4350 ft-tvd) and OGOC at 4360 ft-tvd.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at 4370 ft-tvd

formatted-caption.caption-text: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at 4370 ft-tvd

linkTarget.anchoringText: The history-match result for the OGOC sensitivity runs are shown only for A4-2p as its model produced GOR is more sensitive to assumed OGOC since it is completed higher in the reservoir than A4-1p. Figures 10 to Figure 12 show the effect of varying OGOC on the history-match quality for A4-2p. In Figures 10 to 12, the blue colored lines are the base case model, the red colored lines are the runs from sensitivity of the OGOC, while the green colored circles are the actual historical data. Figure 10 shows the comparison between the history-match quality for the base case (OGOC at 4350 ft-tvd) and OGOC at 4360 ft-tvd.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at HKO (4383 ft-tvd)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A4-2p History Match Plot Comparison between Base Model and Model with OGOC at HKO (4383 ft-tvd)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using the D-Optimal experimental design, 500 simulation runs were made of which 98% of the runs matched the oil rate constraints. However, 44 runs achieved acceptable history-match quality. Figures 13 and 14 show the history-match plots for A4-1p and A4-2p for the 44 runs that achieved acceptable history-match. Considering the OGOCs, Figure 15 shows the histograms of the OGOCs with the blue-shaded bars indicating cases where history match was met, while gray-shaded bars indicate cases where history match was not met.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: History-match plot of A4-1p for the D-Optimal runs that met history match criteria

formatted-caption.caption-text: History-match plot of A4-1p for the D-Optimal runs that met history match criteria

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram of OGOCs from D-Optimal Runs

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 16 shows the histogram for OGOCs based on Monte Carlo simulation runs on the proxy models. The blue-shaded bars indicate cases where history match was met, while gray-shaded bars indicate where history match was not met. The histogram for the OGOC of the Main block suggests that OGOC of the Main block is more likely to be shallower than 4350 ft-tvd and less likely to be deeper than 4350ft-tvd. The histogram for the West block suggests that the full range of the OGOC of the West block resulted in acceptable history-matches.
linkTarget.label: Figure 16

image-wrap.caption: Histogram of OGOCs from Monte Carlo Simulation runs on the Proxy Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histogram of OGOCs from Monte Carlo Simulation runs on the Proxy Model

linkTarget.anchoringText: The histogram for the OGOC of the Main block suggests that OGOC of the Main block is more likely to be shallower than 4350 ft-tvd and less likely to be deeper than 4350ft-tvd. The histogram for the West block suggests that the full range of the OGOC of the West block resulted in acceptable history-matches. Figure 17 shows the cumulative probability distribution plots for the OGOC from the Monte Carlo simulation runs on the proxy model. From the plot, the P10 of the OGOC of the Main block is 4359 ft-tvd which is 24 ft. shallower than the Main block HKO.
linkTarget.label: Figure 17

image-wrap.caption: Cumulative Probability Distribution Plots of OGOCs from Monte Carlo Simulation runs on the Proxy Model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative Probability Distribution Plots of OGOCs from Monte Carlo Simulation runs on the Proxy Model
